page.title: 20The Sanquhar Post
page.content: Sanquhar Post Office is the oldest post office in Britain. The earliest known existence of a PO is an entry in the Edinburgh Almanack of 1763, which states that the post from Sanquhar left Edinburgh on Saturday evenings at 9pm and returned the following Friday afternoon. Letters were a sheet of paper folded, sealed with the address written on the outside. The office was a room in the postmaster's house with a window onto the street through which letters could be handed in or delivered to the caller. By 1788, the mail was being delivered to Sanquhar from Edinburgh 3 times weekly. The earliest reference to Sanquhar in English PO records is dated 1802, when a 3 day post between Cumnock and Sanquhar was recommended. Today there is a postmaster, his 2 assistants and 4 postmen for the official business.
